guest.name: Alex Komoroske
guest.title: Founder (Stealth Startup)
guest.background: Spent 13 years at Google leading Chrome's Open Web Platform and AR, served as Head of Corporate Strategy at Stripe. Known for 'Bits and Bobs' and applying complexity science to organizational management.

episodeSummary: Alex Komoroske joins Lenny to discuss the shift from industrial 'builder' mindsets to complexity-aware 'gardening' mindsets. He explores how Large Language Models (LLMs) act as 'magical duct tape,' how to navigate 'Organizational Kayfabe' (the shared illusions within companies), and how to generate emergent strategy through 'Nerd Clubs.' The conversation focuses on adapting to uncertainty, leveraging bottom-up emergence, and maintaining agency in large systems.

methodologies.name: The Gardening Mindset
methodologies.summary: A shift from the 'Builder' mindset (rigid plans, top-down control) to a 'Gardener' mindset (creating conditions for growth, ecosystem curation). It prioritizes planting many cheap 'seeds' (ideas/prototypes) and investing in the ones that show organic traction (emergence).
principles: Allocate 70% of effort to legible, 'boring' value to buy cover.
Use 30% of time to plant 'acorns' (seeds) with compounding potential.
Don't try to predict the winner; look for signals of natural growth.
Protect the seedlings from 'squirrels' (organizational immune system).
methodologies.problemItSolves: Mitigates the risk of 'Builder' plans that consume more value than they create and fail to adapt to complex, changing environments.
methodologies.whenToUse: When dealing with ecosystems, network effects, or high-uncertainty environments where the 'right' answer cannot be known in advance.
methodologies.commonMistakes: Expecting immediate ROI on every seed; trying to force a specific seed to grow; failing to provide 'cover fire' (legible value) to protect the experiments.
methodologies.quote: What I look for instead are things that can be gardened, things that can grow on their own... If you do this properly, it looks like magic.
methodologies.realWorldExample: Building an open-source tool; if a developer uses it, invest more. If not, the cost was low (hours, not months).

methodologies.name: Strategy Salons (Nerd Clubs)
methodologies.summary: A methodology for generating rigorous strategy in complex environments by creating secret, low-stakes communities ('Nerd Clubs') where diverse perspectives collide. It relies on psychological safety to surface 'yes, and' ideas that eventually coalesce into breakthrough strategies.
principles: Start with a small 'seed crystal' of high-energy people.
Establish a 'Secret' and 'Nerd' vibe to filter for intrinsic motivation.
Enforce 'Yes, And' norms; ignore bad ideas rather than critiquing them.
Dribble in diverse perspectives (novelty search) over time.
methodologies.problemItSolves: Overcomes the 'design by committee' failure mode and the inability of formal executive reviews to handle ambiguous, complex problem domains.
methodologies.whenToUse: When creating strategy for a new domain, solving a cross-functional problem where no single team owns the answer, or trying to break out of groupthink.
methodologies.commonMistakes: Inviting people who 'poop the party' (critics/cynics); letting the chat go silent (death spiral); forcing a specific outcome rather than letting it emerge.
methodologies.quote: You get a group that people find intrinsically valuable for its own sake... that also stochastically spins off changing insights for the surrounding context.
methodologies.realWorldExample: Creating a 'Navel Gazers' group at Google to align 12 different groups without expensive, adversarial executive reviews.

steps: Seed the Group: Invite 3-4 high-energy people who already resonate.
Set Norms: Define as 'Secret' & 'Yes, And' (collaborative debate).
Inject Novelty: Incrementally add diverse perspectives (1-3/week).
Feed the Flame: Facilitator prompts sharing & validates contributions publicly.
Escalate: Organize a live event (lunch) only when demand is high.
Sustain: Send 'FOMO' notes to non-attendees to maintain momentum.

methodologies.name: Navigating Organizational Kayfabe
methodologies.summary: A framework for surviving and influencing large organizations by acknowledging 'Kayfabe' (the shared fake reality/optimism) without becoming a zombie or a martyr. It involves maintaining a 'split brain'â€”playing the role required by the org while holding onto ground truth internally.
principles: Acknowledge that Kayfabe (optimism/white lies) is the lubricant of large orgs.
Recognize that 'hitting the Ground Truth button' (exposing the lie) triggers the organizational immune system.
Maintain a 'split brain': Act in accordance with Kayfabe but make decisions based on reality.
Nudge the system gently rather than shattering the illusion.
methodologies.problemItSolves: Prevents burnout and 'martyrdom' (getting fired for speaking truth too bluntly) while avoiding the 'Zombie Organization' state where everyone believes the fake narrative.
methodologies.whenToUse: When you see the official strategy is doomed but leadership isn't ready to hear it; dealing with status updates in large hierarchies.
methodologies.commonMistakes: Being cynical (checking out); being a 'radical truth teller' at the wrong time (getting tackled); confusing the Kayfabe for reality (becoming a zombie).
methodologies.quote: If you acknowledge the kayfabe is false, then you are in danger of getting knocked out of the game... The easiest way to maintain this split-brain thing is to just turn this part off and just earnestly believe the kayfabe.
methodologies.realWorldExample: A project status is 'yellow' but reported as 'green' because it will be fixed by the time leadership sees it; compounding this up 5 layers creates total disconnection from reality.

dos: Do: Maintain a 'split brain' (Perform the role vs. Know the truth)
Do: Nudge the system incrementally towards reality
Do: Use 'I wonder' framing to introduce disconfirming evidence safely
Do: Accept Kayfabe as a necessary survival mechanic, not malice
donts: Don't: Smash the 'Ground Truth Button' (expose the lie abruptly)
Don't: Believe the Kayfabe earnestly (Zombie state)
Don't: Assume leaders are bad actors; they are trapped in the same system
